EARTHQUAKE AND TSUNAMI EMERGENCY SUPPORT PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Beneficiary  Republic of Indonesia—the people affected by the 26 December 2004 
earthquake and tsunami disaster. 
 
Classification  Targeting Classification: Targeted Intervention 
   
  Sector: Multisector 
   
Subsectors:  Five  sector  groupings:  (i)  livelihood  restoration 
(agriculture, fisheries, and microenterprises), (ii) social services (health 
and  education,  including  skills  development),  (iii)  community 
infrastructure  (rural  water  supply  and  sanitation,  housing,  and 
irrigation), (iv) physical infrastructure (roads and bridges, power, and 
spatial  planning  and  environmental  management), and (v) fiduciary 
governance 
 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, Governance 
 
Subthemes:  Physical  infrastructure  development,  development  of 
urban and rural areas, public governance, and civil society participation 
 
Environment  Category B: An initial environmental examination was undertaken. 
Assessment 
Project Description  The Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Support Project (ETESP) will 
provide rehabilitation and reconstruction assistance to mitigate damage 
caused by the devastating December 2004 earthquake and tsunami. It 
will help restore essential public services, rebuild infrastructure, and 
revive  economic  activity  through  livelihood  support.  The  ETESP  is 
based on the findings of the joint damage and loss assessment, and 
the emerging disaster management, rehabilitation, and reconstruction 
(DMRR) strategy for Aceh and North Sumatra, jointly prepared by the 
Government  of  Indonesia  and  the  donor  community,  with  active 
participation of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Consultations with 
communities and nongovernment organizations have been undertaken, 
and will be intensified in the process of formulating and implementing 
subprojects under the ETESP. In view of the scale, complexity, and 
nature  of  the  disaster,  the  ETESP  adopts  a  two-phase approach, 
focusing  first  on  providing  development  support  to  less-affected 
regions,  along  with  launching  assessments  in  the  most-affected 
regions.  Phase two involves subproject implementation after the spatial 
planning  and  safeguard  issues  are  resolved.  The  ETESP  will 
complement emergency assistance work launched by ADB through the 
reprogramming  of  11  ongoing  projects  and  adding  an  Aceh-North 
Sumatra component to the proposed Community Water Services and 
Health Project.  
   
Rationale  Among  the  affected  countries,  the  impact  of  the  December  2004 
earthquake and tsunami was the most vicious in Indonesia, as evident 
from the loss of 126,000 lives, 94,470 people missing, and 412,438 
internally displaced. About 20% of the population of Aceh province is

ii   
homeless today.   In  North Sumatra, the death toll was about 215.  
About 20% of the area of Nias Islands was damaged. Besides the 
grave tragedy and trauma, the disaster resulted in complete destruction 
of most infrastructure along the coastlines, leading to a total collapse of 
public  services,  major  loss  of  private  property,  and  virtual  loss  of 
livelihood.  
 
In the inland, the earthquake caused substantive damage to buildings 
and infrastructure. The tsunami swept debris and seawater up to 5 
kilometers inland, crushing and damaging buildings, roads, bridges, 
telecommunications,  water  and  electricity  systems,  fisheries 
infrastructure, crops, fuel outlets, and food warehouses. Those who 
survived the disaster suffer from tremendous trauma because of loss of 
families and relatives, as well as loss of livelihood and access to basic 
shelter  and  services.  The  internally  displaced  people,  who  have 
relocated to other communities or temporary camps and shelters, have 
brought  on  challenges  and  distress  to  the  already  poor  and 
overstretched  community  and  public  services.  Most  of  the  public 
infrastructure along the western coast must be rehabilitated or rebuilt, 
while  the  human  and  social  dimensions  of  the  disaster  call  for 
concerted efforts to revive lives and livelihoods, and resurrect entire 
communities. 
 
The provincial and local governments, which had already low budgets 
and weak delivery capacity due to years of civil conflict, have lost 
offices and staff. Restoring normalcy is key to helping people get over 
their  trauma,  but  the  cost  and  challenges  of  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction are phenomenal. The damages and losses, estimated at 
$4.7 billion, are the largest requirement among the affected regions in 
Asia. During the development partner meeting in January 2005, donors 
pledged $1.7 billion to meet part of these requirements. ADB’s support 
will help meet the immediate requirements based on the joint damage 
and loss assessment and the DMRR strategy. 
   
Objectives  The overall goal of the ETESP is to help rebuild the affected regions 
and support their economic revival to meet the Millennium Development 
Goals. Its purpose is to (i) facilitate economic revival in the affected 
regions by restoring livelihoods; and (ii) alleviate constraints due to the 
lack of adequate public goods and facilities by restoring essential public 
services and rebuilding infrastructure. 
 
To meet the critical DMRR needs in a flexible manner, the ETESP is 
designed as a multisector project facility that follows the sector loan 
approach. It consists of five principal sector groupings: 
 
(i)  Livelihood restoration. Rehabilitate the agriculture and 
fisheries  sectors,  the  mainstay  of  a  majority  of  the 
Acehnese, and revive micro and small enterprises. 
 
(ii)  Social services provision.  Rehabilitate and reconstruct 
health  and  education  facilities,  and  support  skills

iii 
development of the affected population through vocational 
training. 
 
(iii)  Community infrastructure. Provide water and sanitation 
facilities, rebuild irrigation infrastructure, and rehabilitate 
and reconstruct the damaged and lost housing stock within 
an integrated community development framework. 
 
(iv)  Physical infrastructure. Rebuild the damaged roads and 
bridges,  restore  power  supply,  support  sound  spatial 
planning,  and  strengthen  environmental  management 
systems. 
 
(v)  Fiduciary  governance.  Ensure  sound  oversight  of  the 
utilization  of  donor  funds  in  the  DMRR  process,  and 
facilitate effective delivery of ETESP assistance. 
   
Cost Estimates   The total cost of the ETESP is estimated at $321.5 million equivalent.  
   
Financing Plan  A grant of $290.0 million from the Asian Tsunami Fund resources of the 
ADB  will  be  provided  to  finance  the  ETESP.  In  addition,  the 
Netherlands  Government  will  provide  $3.5 million  for the fiduciary 
oversight  support  component  of  the  ETESP.  The  Government  of 
Indonesia  will finance the remaining $28.0 million equivalent of the 
costs covering local taxes and other regular administrative costs.

Implementation  The  Government  is  establishing  an  Aceh  Reconstruction 
Arrangements  Implementation Coordination Board (BKP) to coordinate and implement 
DMRR. BKP  will provide an interface between the central and local 
governments and ensure effective involvement of the Acehnese people. 
BKP  will  comprise  a  steering  board,  supervisory  board,  and  an 
implementation  coordination  board.  The  steering  board  will  include 
selected  ministers,  the  governor  of  Aceh,  the  governor  of  north 
Sumatra,  heads  of  affected  districts,  academics,  community 
representatives  and  religious  leaders.  It  will  provide  inputs  and 
recommendations in formulating, planning and implementing the DMRR 
process, and submit reports to the President of Indonesia once every 
four months. The supervisory board will comprise  representatives of 
civil  society,  local  universities,  local  media,  nongovernment 
organizations, and donors (bilateral and multilateral). It will oversee the 
activities of the BKP, receive and follow up on complaints from the 
public, and coordinate independent audits on the functioning of the 
BKP.  The  implementation  board,  comprising  the  head  of  BKP,  its 
secretary,  and  deputies  of  BKP’s  operational  departments,  will 
formulate operational policies, implement projects in coordination with 
other  relevant  Government  institutions,  and  ensure  overall  sound 
fiduciary governance in the utilization of donor support and other public 
funds in the DMRR process.

iv   
Once established, the BKP will be the Executing Agency. In the interim, 
BAPPENAS will function as the Executing Agency and once BKP is 
established the role and responsibilities of the Executing Agency will be 
transferred  from  BAPPENAS  to  BKP.  BKP  will be responsible for 
overall  management  and  coordination  of  ETESP  and  its 
implementation, in close collaboration with the line ministries. For the 
day-to-day  project  management,  a  dedicated,  centralized  project 
management office will be established within BKP, with staffing and 
other support provided by the ETESP. The project management office 
will  review  and  appraise  subprojects  for  BKP’s consideration, and 
ensure overall governance and fiduciary controls on the utilization of 
ETESP funds. The design of subprojects and their implementation will 
be  under  the  responsibility  of  the  respective  line  ministries,  in 
collaboration with local governments.  
 
The Extended Mission of Sumatra, being established by ADB, will be 
responsible for managing, administering, and implementing the ETESP. 
Located in Medan with an office in Banda Aceh, the Mission will work 
closely  with  BKP;  project  management  office;  and  the  central, 
provincial,  and  local  governments  to  structure  and  implement  the 
subprojects.

Procurement  Given the emergency DMRR needs, procurement of goods, services, 
and works will be carried out in a manner consistent with the simplified 
and  expedient  procedures  permitted  under  the  ADB  Disaster  and 
Emergency Assistance Policy and ADB Guidelines for Procurement, in 
general. ADB procedures for providing reconstruction assistance after 
disasters allow maximum flexibility, so that project activities can start 
promptly. National procurement will be the preferred mode for all civil 
works  because  of  the  relatively  short  implementation  period,  the 
generally small size of contract packages, and the wide geographic 
spread of the project sites. Community participation in procurement will 
be encouraged, and local goods and services will be given priority to 
encourage economic revival in the affected regions. 
   
Consulting Services  All  consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB,  in  consultation  with  the 
Government,  in  accordance  with  ADB  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Simplified consultant selection 
procedures, including direct selection and shorter evaluation periods, 
will be followed in line with the flexibility provided under ADB’s Disaster 
and Emergency Assistance Policy. 
   
Multidonor Trust  The Government is coordinating the establishment of a multidonor trust 
Fund  fund  (MDTF),  which  is  expected  to  attract  contributions  of  several 
donors.  MDTF is a vehicle to pool bilateral resources in order to 
channel  these  through  the  budget  to  ensure  a  systematic  and

v
coordinated approach to the rehabilitation and reconstruction of the 
affected regions. It is proposed that ADB contribute $10 million from the 
Asian Tsunami Fund to the MDTF to facilitate coordination between the 
ETESP and support from the other donors through the MDTF.

Risks and  ETESP implementation involves three major risks: (i) the history of 
Assumptions  prolonged conflicts in Aceh; (ii) lack of adequate capacity at the local 
government levels in the devastated regions; and (iii) lack of coherence 
in the implementation of rehabilitation and reconstruction, and lack of 
donor coordination. The ETESP design aims to mitigate  these risks. 
The tsunami tragedy has provided a small window of opportunity for the 
Government and the Free Aceh Movement to discuss  Aceh’s future. 
Peace  talks  have  been  initiated  in  Helsinki  and  the  Free  Aceh 
Movement. As an interim measure, the Free Aceh Movement and the 
Government have agreed to a temporary cease fire. Another important 
mitigating  factor  is  the  level  of  seriousness  and  commitment  the 
Government  has  shown  in  preparing  the  DMRR  strategy,  and  in 
mobilizing donor commitments.  ETESP design deals with the conflict 
risk  by  recognizing  that  the  reconstruction effort needs  to  be fully 
participatory.  
 
With regard to capacity constraints, the ETESP recognizes the serious 
local problems to be  faced. This capacity risk will be mitigated by 
including capacity-building support for local governments in all sector 
and  subproject  interventions,  and  providing  adequate  support  for 
project management and implementation.  
 
The ETESP’s flexible design will help mitigate coordination risks by 
formulating sector interventions under two phases. This is to allow for 
adequate time and consultations with central and local governments 
and  donors.  The  subproject  proposals  will  pass  through  a 
comprehensive assessment process, including in-depth consultations 
with all relevant and major institutions concerned. 
In addition, the segregation of women and persistence of gender-based 
discriminatory  practices  in  Aceh  may  affect  the  ETESP’s  ability  to 
identify specific needs and vulnerabilities of women, especially widows 
and  female  heads  of  households,  in  order  to  formulate  adequate 
response.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  ETESP  components  will  support 
community organizations, including women’s grassroots organizations 
and networks, to participate in local decision-making to ensure that their 
perspectives  are  included  in  mainstream  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction efforts.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
grant to Republic of Indonesia for the Earthquake  and Tsunami Emergency Support Project 
(ETESP); (ii) proposed administration of a grant from the Government of the Netherlands for the 
ETESP; and (iii) a contribution to the Multidonor Trust Fund (MDTF).  
 
II.  RATIONALE: ANALYSIS, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  The 26 December 2004 Tsunami 
2.  Tsunamis have been recorded for several centuries, though the frequency of their 
occurrence in the Indian Ocean is low relative to the Pacific where over 300 tsunamis have 
been recorded. While Sumatra’s west coast has experienced tidal waves, the event of 26 
December 2004  was the worst in recent history. The earthquake that triggered the tsunami 
occurred at 7:58 am local time (1:58 pm Greenwich mean time), with its epicenter about 250 
kilometers (km) from Banda Aceh, the capital of Aceh  province, and about 150 km south of 
Meulaboh, off the coast of Sumatra. Originating at a relatively shallow depth of 30 km below the 
Indian Ocean, the earthquake was recorded at 9.0 on the Richter scale, making it the fifth 
largest in recorded history, and the worst natural disaster since the eruption of Krakatoa in 
Indonesia in 1883, in terms of energy released.  
 
3.  The United States Geological Survey estimates that up to 1,200 km of the India Plate 
boundary has likely slipped  as a result of the powerful quake. It caused an initial rupture  of 
about 100 km wide, and an estimated vertical displacement of 15 meters along the fault line. 
The tsunami triggered by the massive displacement on the seafloor caused unprecedented 
damage in Aceh province in northern Sumatra (Maps). Fourteen of 21 districts (kabupaten), 
primarily in the coastal areas of the province, were significantly damaged, while interior areas 
suffered serious earthquake damage. The tsunami devastated coastal areas in India, Maldives, 
Sri Lanka, Thailand, and to some extent in Bangladesh and Myanmar. Its impact was felt as far 
west as Africa. 
 
4.  As of 5 March 2005, the Government of Indonesia (the Government) reported 126,000 
dead, 94,470 missing, and 412,438 internally displaced. In Aceh province, with a population of 
3.9 million, over 10% were left homeless. In North Sumatra, the death toll was over 200 and 
about 20% of the area of Nias Islands was damaged. The disaster has totally devastated 
livelihoods and damaged private and public property. Public infrastructure collapsed along the 
coastal lines, and inland destruction was significant due to the earthquake. The tsunami swept 
debris and seawater up to 5 km inland, crushing and damaging buildings, roads, bridges, 
telecommunications, water and electricity systems, fisheries infrastructure, crops, fuel outlets, 
and food warehouses. To restore normalcy, infrastructure must be rehabilitated or rebuilt along 
the west coast, while the human and social dimensions of the disaster call for concerted efforts 
to revive lives and livelihoods and resurrect entire communities.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  The Government’s Response and the Damage and Loss Assessment 
5.  The  Government  swiftly  responded  in  the  immediate  aftermath  of  the  disaster.  Its 
emergency, rescue, and relief efforts were coordinated by the National Coordination Board for 
Disaster Management under the Vice President’s Office and the Coordinating Ministry for

2  
People’s Welfare. The  National Coordination Board  was assigned overall responsibility for 
recovering and burying the dead; placing the survivors in shelters; distributing water, food, 
blankets, and essential medicines; and undertaking emergency removal and disposal of debris. 
As Aceh was still under a state of civil emergency under the central Government’s jurisdiction, 
the Ministry of Home Affairs sent in staff to run the local administration and manage public 
service  responsibilities  of  the  devastated  districts  and  villages.  The  United  Nations  (UN) 
supported the relief and humanitarian assistance. Bilateral institutions and armed forces of 
several countries also played an important role in the initial emergency and relief efforts.  
 
6.  The scale of the tragedy and the tremendous loss of human lives have led to a massive 
mobilization of emergency support and commitments from the world community for future 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction.  In  order  to  effectively  coordinate  the  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction process and channel domestic and international assistance, in  early January 
2005,  the  President  of  Indonesia  tasked  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency 
(BAPPENAS) with the formulation of a medium-term disaster management, rehabilitation, and 
reconstruction (DMRR) strategy, to be completed by end-March 2005. On 26 March 2005, Vice 
President unveiled a 12-volume DMRR blueprint for Aceh reconstruction in Banda Aceh, for 
public  consultation.  A  Presidential  Decree  on  the  establishment  of  a  new  Implementation 
Coordination Board for Aceh-North Sumatra Rehabilitation and Reconstruction (BKP) , which 
will be tasked with the implementation of the the DMRR blueprint, is anticipated in April 2005.   
 
7.  Damage and Loss Assessment. The earthquake and tsunami destroyed large parts of 
Banda Aceh; the nearby districts of Aceh Besar and Aceh Jaya; Meulaboh, the capital of West 
Aceh and Lhokseumawe in North Aceh. Coastal areas of other districts were also affected, but 
with  less  severity,  including  East  Aceh,  Nagan  Raya,  Simeuleue,  South  Aceh,  Pidie, and 
Bireuen. To estimate the material impact of the disaster, the Government, with coordination by 
BAPPENAS, and donors jointly undertook a comprehensive damage and loss assessment 
(DLA). The DLA exercise,1 which covered 15 sectors, focused on the damage to public and 
private infrastructure (stock) and on the loss of income (flow) stemming from the widespread 
destruction of productive assets and the environment.  
 
8.  Overall damage and losses, as estimated on a replacement basis by the joint DLA team, 
amount to about $4.7 billion, representing 2.3% of the national gross domestic product (GDP) 
and about 115% of the annual regional GDP of Aceh province. Of this, 37% of the damage was 
incurred in the social sectors (including housing, education, and health); 25% in the productive 
sectors  (including  agriculture,  fisheries,  and  industry  and  trade);  19%  in  the  infrastructure 
sectors (including energy, transport, communications, water and sanitation, irrigation, and flood 
control); and 19% in the environment, governance, and financial sectors. Damage to personal 
property,  particularly  housing,  has  been  pervasive.  Reconstruction  and  restoration  of  lost 
housing stock alone will require $1.4 billion. Reconstruction needs may be significantly different 
and costs considerably higher if the Government and Acehnese residents decide to rebuild 
communities in different locations or to provide better public facilities and services than before.

9.  Secessionist Conflict. Over the past 2 decades, the civilian and secessionist conflict in 
Aceh has claimed the lives of about 10,000 people. After several attempts at allowing civil 
administration, the central Government again imposed martial law in May 2003; this was relaxed 
to a state of civil emergency for 6 months beginning in May 2004. Now, the central Government 
has declared the earthquake and  tsunami as national disasters and  it is providing greater 
administration support to the province. Immediately following the disaster, Indonesia’s armed 
forces announced a cease-fire to facilitate relief efforts, which was accepted by the Free Aceh 
Movement. Subsequently, the Government has declared a temporary cease fire and engaged in 
peace talks with the Free Aceh Movement. Prospects for early resolution of issues surrounding 
the conflict are complicated by the movement’s demands for full political autonomy bordering on 
independence.  
 
10.  Economic  Context  and  Impact.    Years  of  conflict  have  eroded  the  physical 
infrastructure and facilities and rendered it difficult to provide effectively functioning basic social 
services in Aceh. While general health and education indicators in Aceh were comparable to

4  
national averages, the conflict has had a disproportionate impact on social infrastructure in two 
ways. First, services in rural areas were neglected due to declining investments as well as 
security concerns at subdistrict and village levels. Second, more than 900 schools have been 
destroyed or severely damaged since 1998 as a result of the conflict. At a broader level, the 
conflict  has  eroded  public  and  investor  confidence.  Until  the  tragedy,  international 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  had  been  barred  from  operating  in  Aceh,  while 
assistance from multilateral and bilateral agencies was low because of operational difficulties. 
 
11.  In 2003, Aceh’s regional GDP was Rp38.6 trillion ($4.1 billion), accounting for a little 
over 2% of national GDP. Real GDP grew at 3.4% in 2003, relative to the national GDP growth 
rate of 4.3%. On a sector basis, oil and gas had the largest share of GDP at 43%, followed by 
agriculture at 32%. Almost half of Aceh’s labor force of 2.3 million is employed in the agriculture 
sector. Given its special status and abundant resources, Aceh receives a greater share of 
revenues  from  its  natural  resources  (primarily  oil  and  gas),  since  the  introduction  of 
decentralization in 1999, relative to other provinces. For instance, until 2009 Aceh is to receive 
70% of the oil revenues generated, while other provinces receive only 15% (with the exception 
of Papua), and the ratios are 40% and 30%, respectively, for gas revenues.  
 
12.  Given the scale of the disaster and the significant loss of private productive assets, the 
macroeconomic impact of the disaster is likely to range from a 0.1 to 0.5 percentage point drop 
in the national GDP growth rate of 5.5% projected for 2005. Yet, if the rehabilitation and 
reconstruction activities gain momentum with replacement private and public investments made, 
the negative impact may be contained. 
 
13.  Social and Poverty Impact. Based on a field survey, the Central Statistical Agency has 
determined that 660 Acehnese villages, including outskirts of urban areas, with a combined 
population of 650,000 were affected. The disaster struck a sizable proportion of the economy, 
particularly major market and service centers such as Bandah Aceh, Calang, and Meulaboh, 
which bore the brunt of the impact. It struck individuals, households, communities, social 
organizations, and economic chains. Acehnese communities are cohesive, and people live in 
concentrated areas. The community is the repository of information about resources, assets, 
ownership, and identity.  Community social institutions responsible for organizing social and 
personal lives and mitigating conflict have suffered losses and incapacitation of key persons. 
This increases the probability of community tensions aggravated further by the sudden influx of 
internally  displaced  people.  The  multiple  role  of  women—heading  households;  sustaining 
subsistence economies; raising children; and caring for the sick, elderly, and wounded—has 
come to form the lifeline of Acehnese communities. In the rebuilding phase, emphasis needs to 
be placed on restoring and securing women’s livelihoods and supporting women’s groups and 
networks whose survival strategies are holding communities together. Such support will be vital 
to rapidly and holistically advancing emotional, social, and economic recovery in the tsunami-
affected areas. 
 
14.  Despite the conflict, the province kept pace with the rest of Indonesia in general terms. 
Furthermore, as Aceh was outside of the El Nino belt that afflicted much of Indonesia in 1997 
and 1998, its agriculture-based economy with little manufacturing or trade and relatively small 
exposure to the financial system isolated it from most of the impacts of the crises of those years. 
The  incidence  of  poverty  in  Aceh  remained  lower  than  the  national  average  until  2001. 
Subsequently, however, the trend reversed, and in 2003 Aceh ranked as the third poorest 
province after Papua and Maluku, most likely stemming from the conflict. The disaster is likely to 
affect  the  poor  disproportionately,  by  cutting  access  to  essential  public  services.  Thus

5
compensation and asset restoration  must be well targeted to ensure that the needy receive 
such support. 
 
15.  Environmental  Impact.  The  earthquake  and  tsunami  have  caused  serious 
environmental damage, estimated at above $660 million (Table 1, note). About one fourth is 
attributable to direct destruction of environmental assets, while the remaining corresponds to the 
loss of benefits from environmental assets such as coral reefs and forests, which will need at 
least a generation to regenerate. The geography of the affected regions is characterized by a 
mountain ridge running from the west to the southeast. The coastal plains  are developed, 
except along most of the western coast. The regions have a diverse range of ecosystems and 
foliage, including coral reefs, mangroves, and different types of forests. On the approximately 
100,000 hectares (ha) of coastal reefs in the affected regions, about 30% have live coral. The 
province also has rich water resources, including rivers, lakes, wetlands, and groundwater 
systems.  The  disaster  had  an  enormous  impact  on  the  environment  in  general,  inflicting 
damage  on  ecosystems,  plants  and  habitats,  and  animals.  Two  particular  issues  are 
noteworthy. The disaster generated vast quantities of debris and spread sewage and industrial 
waste and damaged the ecosystem. It also appears to have altered coastal lines, as well as 
affecting land surface and soil quality. 
 
2.  The Government’s Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Strategy 
16.  BAPPENAS and the development partners have formulated the DMRR strategy2 for 
restoration of normal life in Aceh and North Sumatra. The strategy distinguishes between three 
partly overlapping phases: immediate emergency and relief operations to be completed within 
the first 6 months (by June 2005); the rehabilitation phase, which will cover 0.5–2 years; and 
reconstruction activities to be initiated along with rehabilitation and carried out over 5 years. The 
strategy focuses on:  
 
•  Restoring Lives and Livelihoods. The Government aims to (i) design and implement 
labor-intensive public works in the short term, (ii) provide the opportunity for families to 
rebuild their own homes, (iii) support families and communities where displaced people 
have taken refuge, (iv) provide compensation from budgetary resources in a transparent 
manner,  and  (v)  rebuild  land  registration  offices  and  formulate  effective  dispute 
resolution procedures. 
 
•  Restoring  Economic  Activity.  The  Government  will  (i)  emphasize  labor-intensive 
infrastructure investments, and purchase all goods and services locally to the extent 
possible;  (ii)  recapitalize  household  and  small  enterprises  with  grants;  (iii)  restore 
banking and essential financial services quickly; (iv) minimize local and international 
trade barriers to control price hikes; and (v) reestablish retail and wholesale markets, 
including information centers. 
 
•  Restoring  Infrastructure.  The  Government  aims  to  (i)  rebuild  strategic  roads  and 
bridges quickly,  and realign some roads as needed as part of the spatial planning 
process;  (ii)  rebuild  air  and  seaports;  (iii)  repair  power  and  telecommunication 
infrastructure;  and  (iv)  restore  clean  water  supply,  through  temporary  measures  to 
provide water, and cleaning, desalination, and redigging of wells.

governments in Aceh and North Sumatra recover their lost capacities. 
 
17.  The Government has adopted certain core principles to guide DMRR, including (a) using 
participatory  decision-making  by  empowering  the  people  of  Aceh;  (b)  ensuring  sound 
coordination,  for  consistency  and  effectiveness  across  sectors  and  regions;  (c)  utilizing  a 
comprehensive approach to rebuilding communities, based on in-depth spatial planning and 
location analyses; (d) distinguishing between rehabilitation (to achieve minimum standards) and 
reconstruction (to enable Acehnese to move forward); (e) restoring human resource capacity 
across all sectors, and focusing on delivery of services and strengthening institutions rather than 
on projects; and (f) ensuring full fiscal transparency and effective monitoring.  
 
  3.  Development Partners’ Response 
18.  The response from the international community has been swift. Army, air force, and navy 
units from  several  countries  supported  the  rescue  and  relief  operations  in  the  immediate 
aftermath of the disaster, working alongside various UN agencies. The 6 January 2005 Asian 
Tsunami  Summit  held  in  Jakarta  led  to  an  outpouring  of  support  from  the  international 
community. Many development partners worked collectively with the Government to prepare the 
DLA and the DMRR strategy. The subsequent UN Flash Appeal resulted in a contribution of 
close to $370 million for Indonesia. At the Consultative Group on Indonesia meeting held in 
January 2005, donors committed $1.7 billion for rehabilitation and reconstruction support in 
2005; of this, $1.0 billion is estimated to be channeled through the budget. Several bilateral 
donors have pledged significant contributions, including Australia (about $780 million in grants 
and soft loans), United States (about $450 million in grants), and European Union (about $265 
million in grants). Other countries, including Canada, Germany, Japan, Netherlands, and United 
Kingdom  are  formulating  significant  support  initiatives.  BAPPENAS  is  coordinating  the 
establishment of a multidonor trust fund (MDTF), which is expected to attract contributions of 
several donors.  MDTF is seen as a vehicle largely to pool bilateral resources  in order to 
channel these through  the budget to ensure  a systematic and coordinated approach to  the 
rehabilitation and reconstruction of Aceh and North Sumatra (para.23, and 91-93).

23.  Furthermore, ADB has had intensive discussions with the Government and the World

  5.  Lessons and Principles Incorporated in ETESP Design 
24.  The rehabilitation and reconstruction needs are staggering. Quite different from the other 
affected countries, the rebuilding of Aceh is likely to be more challenging given the state of the 
political economy, level of development of the province, and relatively weak capacity to absorb 
large assistance flows equivalent to about a quarter of  Aceh’s GDP every year for the next 4 
years. Based on these factors and ADB’s past experience with emergency assistance, at least 
six major challenges and lessons have guided ETESP design.  
 
25.  First, dealing with a natural disaster of this magnitude in a conflict environment calls for 
a sound approach to rebuilding with participatory mechanisms across the affected areas in a 
transparent and accountable manner. Allocation of resources to different villages and districts

need to be in line with the DLA, accepting that nearly every region in the province has felt some 
degree of stress from this calamity. Unless a conflict-sensitive approach is adopted, prospects 
of genuine reconciliation through rehabilitation and reconstruction are likely to be lost. ADB’s 
past support for conflict-affected communities in Indonesia, for instance in West Timor, has 
demonstrated that resources need to be distributed in a balanced and equitable manner across 
directly and indirectly affected communities. 
 
26.  Second, the rebuilding process will take place in an environment with depleted public 
administration systems, yet one that is decentralized to the district level. The special autonomy 
provisions must be respected, and credibility and trust developed among the affected local 
officials and citizens. As Indonesian decentralization is recent, local government capacity has 
generally been nascent and almost erased in the most affected region/districts. Building local 
capacity, in an incremental manner, to implement programs is critical for ensuring the regional 
autonomy of Aceh and the aspirations of its people. The local governments are being revived 
and have established working groups parallel to those at the central level. Their proposals for 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  will  be  effectively  aligned  with  broader  principles  being 
formulated by the central Government. Sound governance and fiduciary arrangements are 
critical given the weak capacity, as well as the loss of historical records of population and land 
titles. They have to be structured so that they do not impede speedy delivery.  
 
27.  Third, total obliteration in many areas has likely led to radical shifts in the demographic 
and social composition of communities. In coastal and many inland communities, the rebuilding 
process will not be initiated unless carefully considered spatial, resettlement, and environment 
assessments and plans are finalized. The Government has proposed rezoning arrangements for 
coastal areas. This would entail the creation of a buffer zone near the coastline, a medium zone 
of less devastated areas, and an inland zone of least affected areas. In the most affected 
coastal  zones,  rebuilding  local  infrastructure  and  public  facilities  will  have  to  follow  the 
finalization of this process and consultations with the affected communities. Resolution of land 
allocation may prove to be one of the most complex issues, in the absence of community 
leadership in many cases. A consistent policy framework needs to be adopted on land retitling 
and building permits provided to those who want to rebuild in their original locations. As the 
land-titling system was not complete before the tsunami, possession of acceptable documents 
may be rare. A serious challenge is to develop participatory mechanisms to truly enable the 
Acehnese people to determine issues such as those related to spatial location. These issues 
have many implications and demand comprehensive support.  
 
28.  Fourth, with close to 80% of the damage and losses suffered by the private sector, the 
public-private dimensions of the disaster warrant innovative solutions involving the private 
sector. Top priority needs to be assigned to alleviating the public goods constraints by restoring 
and rebuilding vital social and physical infrastructure that is essential for the private sector to 
function. Support programs for  removing private constraints should proceed in parallel, and 
livelihood opportunities need to be restored quickly to provide dignity, comfort, as well as means 
of economic survival to those affected. In particular, the transition from the relief and emergency 
phase to the rehabilitation and reconstruction stage needs to be managed well—recognizing 
that the line between relief and later activities will vary from area to area and is very much a 
function of the level of devastation incurred and local capacity. Restoration of private productive 
assets needs to be actively pursued, through a blend of compensation and targeted support 
schemes. 
 
29.  Fifth, the outpouring of support from within Indonesia and the international community 
means that coordination of support is vital. The Government needs to outline clear principles

9
and  practices  to  guide  the  support  from  the  private  sector,  NGOs,  and  public-private 
partnerships, and has to set up effective mechanisms for donor coordination. The fund flows 
from donors that are channeled through the budget as well as outside of the budget need to be 
carefully monitored, and their impact evaluated and assessed periodically to ensure that the 
DMRR objectives are met. Ensuring sound fiduciary governance is extremely important in the 
postconflict and postdisaster environment given the weak local capacity.  
 
30.  Sixth, deriving from all of these factors, flexibility is paramount in designing the overall 
project and subprojects. Needs should be assessed and reassessed as they emerge during 
implementation of the overall project, and components should be flexible to accommodate 
possible reallocation of resources. Nevertheless, safeguard provisions including environmental 
protection,  and  poverty  reduction  measures  should  be  included  in  the  design.  Adequate 
standards for civil works should be maintained during the rehabilitation and reconstruction 
process. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
31.  The overall goal of the ETESP is to help rebuild the affected regions and support their 
economic revival to meet the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Its purpose is to (i) 
facilitate economic revival in the affected regions by  restoring livelihoods; and (ii) alleviate 
constraints resulting from the lack of public goods and facilities by restoring essential public 
services and rebuilding infrastructure. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Components  
32.  To meet the critical DMRR needs in a flexible manner,  the ETESP is designed as a 
multisector project facility that follows the sector loan approach. It consists of five principal 
sector groupings: 
 
(i)  Livelihood restoration. Rehabilitate the agriculture and fisheries sectors, the 
mainstay of a majority of the Acehnese, and revive micro and small enterprises. 
 
(ii)  Social service provision. Rehabilitate and reconstruct health and education 
facilities,  and  support  skills  development  of  the  affected  population  through 
vocational training. 
 
(iii)  Community  infrastructure.  Provide  water  and  sanitation  facilities,  rebuild 
irrigation infrastructure, and rehabilitate and reconstruct the damaged and lost 
housing stock within an integrated community development framework. 
 
(iv)  Physical infrastructure. Rebuild damaged roads and bridges, restore power 
supply,  support  sound  spatial  planning,  and  strengthen  environmental 
management systems. 
 
(v)  Fiduciary governance. Ensure sound oversight of donor fund utilization in the 
DMRR process, and facilitate effective delivery of ETESP support.

10  
C.  Special Features 
33.  Flexibility in Design and Support. With large areas heavily affected, and over 400,000 
internally displaced people and others directly or indirectly affected needing some form of 
livelihood restoration support; the DMRR process will be complex and time-consuming. The 
Government’s strategy is expected to evolve and change over time to meet emerging needs. 
With damages and losses in billions of dollars, effective coordination between the Government 
and donors, and among the latter, will be essential. DMRR support needs to be channeled in a 
sequenced and seamless manner, recognizing that the relief and emergency operations are 
winding down in many areas, and that rehabilitation activities are already under way in the less 
devastated regions. In view of these factors, a flexible design is adopted for the ETESP. Its key 
features are as follows (Figure 1, page 12): 
 
(i)  Thematic approach. All activities under the ETESP will be categorized under 
two  basic  themes:  facilitating  economic  revival  by  restoring  livelihood,  and 
alleviating public goods constraints by restoring essential public services and 
rebuilding infrastructure.  
 
(ii)  Clustering of sectors. The ETESP will maintain flexibility in the allocation of 
resources within and across the sector groupings (para. 32), to ensure that ADB 
can meet the emerging needs and align its support to the plans of other donors. 
Periodic updates,  with a mapping of donor support as it emerges in various 
sectors,  will  be  provided  in  the  quarterly  reports  on  Asian  Tsunami  Fund 
utilization to the ADB Board of Directors.  
 
(iii)  Phasing of support. As the level of devastation varies across the affected 
regions, ADB support will need to be designed and delivered in a phased manner 
based on readiness. Spatial planning is a key dimension of the DMRR process. 
In the initial stages of phase 1 (on approval of the ETESP), the principal focus 
will be on rebuilding in areas where DMRR can proceed without complex spatial 
decisions  and  on  supporting  preparatory  work,  such  as  spatial  planning, 
resettlement surveys and planning, and environment assessments, in the most 
devastated areas. In phase 2 (tentatively scheduled to begin in the third or fourth 
quarter  of  2005),  once  ground  work  is  undertaken  in  devastated  areas, 
subprojects will be formulated and launched. Both phases will be completed by 
June 2008. 
 
34.  Subproject  Modality.  The  ETESP’s  sector  project  approach  facilitates  designing 
subprojects based on feasibility studies and community consultations. The subproject modality 
will ensure that ADB can effectively coordinate ETESP components with the support provided 
by other donors, including  MDTF subprojects. ETESP subprojects will be designed, where 
feasible,  by  integrating  multisector  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  needs.  Cross-sector 
synergies will be maximized by adopting integrated community development approaches. For 
instance, in the case of the agriculture and fisheries sectors, a subproject will be defined at the 
district level with all its activities aimed at rehabilitating agricultural or fisheries resources and 
the related infrastructure, restoring rural livelihoods, and strengthening the related government 
institutions and farmer organizations. In the case of irrigation, a subproject will be defined as an 
independent irrigation system or a group of inter-linked irrigation systems. Integrated community 
development approaches will be adopted for subprojects in the housing sector. Road sector 
subprojects will be defined as a specific section of a road, along with part or all of the drainage

11
and crossing structures within the section. In the case of the health sector, a subproject will be 
defined at the district level with project support for health care programs. 
 
35.  Addressing the MDG Challenge. In line with its overall goal, the ETESP will be 
structured as a set of subprojects to help the affected regions eventually progress toward the 
MDGs. The goal is based on the premise that the DMRR efforts toward the MDGs must also 
take into account the negative impact of the civil conflict on the quantity and quality of public 
services. The ETESP will support the Government in establishing an MDG monitoring system 
as a decision-making tool to (i) track the overall emergency aid flows to different regions in Aceh 
and North Sumatra, (ii) assess support given the needs, and (iii) redirect aid to underserved 
areas. 
 
D.  Outputs 
 
36.  The ETESP adopts a sequential approach, following on from the support offered by ADB 
under reprogramming of ongoing projects (para. 21 and footnote 3). Appendix 2 contains details

1.  Livelihood Restoration 
37.  Agriculture. The earthquake and tsunami damage to agriculture has been extensive. 
The farmers in the affected areas lost their standing crops and livestock, and will continue to 
incur substantial losses in the medium to long term due to siltation and salinization of farmlands, 
and  damaged  infrastructure  for  irrigation,  drainage,  flood  control,  and  land  erosion.  An 
estimated 40,000 ha of cropland and 37,000 ha of tree crops were damaged. Furthermore, 
140,000 large ruminants, 90,000 small ruminants, and 1.6 million poultry were lost. Total 
damage to agriculture is estimated at $120 million, while income losses until full recovery are 
expected to reach $145 million (Table 1, note). Agricultural support services have also been 
severely affected.  
  
38.  The ETESP will focus on restoring support services, empowering the community, and 
restoring crop farming. The recovery of agriculture will require fully functional and effective 
support services. This calls for (i) capacity building of institutions and human resources; (ii) 
recruitment of agricultural graduates, preferably coming from the affected areas, initially on a 
contractual basis, who may later be absorbed by the district and provincial governments into 
their regular cadres; (iii) training for 250 new and 350 existing staff in the participatory extension 
methodologies,  land  use  planning,  crop  production,  and  remedial  measures  to  address 
salinization and other tsunami-related issues; and (iv) rehabilitation of key agricultural facilities, 
and provision of necessary equipment and vehicles. 
 
39.  Fisheries. Fisheries is one of the hardest hit sectors. Most of the fishing communities in 
the affected areas lost their boats, fishing gear, and equipment; incurred heavy damage to 
fishponds and small-scale processing facilities; and will remain affected in the medium to long 
term by the damage to the coastal resources and the supporting infrastructure, such as fish-
landing  and  auction  market  facilities.  The  restoration  and  recovery  of  livelihoods  may  be 
painstakingly slow. Total damage to the sector is estimated at $260 million. Income losses until 
full recovery are expected at $408 million. Furthermore, the loss to the coastal environment in 
terms of loss of coral reefs, mangroves, and sea-grass bed is estimated at $468 million. 
Fisheries  extension  and  support  services  have  also  been  severally  affected.

component and provide technical assistance to microfinance institutions. The ETESP will

support is needed for reviving livelihoods in the affected regions, and sustainable 
income  generating  capacity  is  a  prerequisite  to  creating  and  expanding 
microfinance  institutions,  including  rural  banks,  many  of  which  are  privately 
owned, and other institutions including savings and credit associations. The 
ETESP, building on the JFPR grant project (para.22), will develop appropriate 
modalities to deliver microfinance support. In particular, the ETESP will establish 
a microfinance fund, to provide funding support for microfinance institutions and 
the  Provincial  Development  Bank  that  seek  to  serve  microenterprises.  The 
ETESP will support such institutions in the areas of  operations, product design, 
financial management, accounting and auditing. 
 
(ii)  Establish an innovation fund. The fund will provide long-term debt and/or 
equity for (a) demonstrably viable financial institutions that want to restore and 
expand their operations in the province, but are short of investment capital; and 
(b) new financial institutions, primarily leasing companies. The fund will support 
financial  innovations,  and  promote  investment  in  new  financial  firms.  Some 
Shariah-based institutions are operating, though on a small scale. Utilizing and 
expanding this risk-sharing financial modality will be worthwhile. Shariah leasing 
is a new concept and appears to offer promise as a way of financing small-scale 
equipment leasing needed by existing and new  micro and small enterprises. 
Local institutions that demonstrate fundamental soundness may be allowed to 
borrow longer term to finance their capital expenditures, including investments in 
new service technologies.

14   
2.       Social Service Provision 
42.  Health. The DLA for the health sector estimated that Aceh suffered damage of $82 
million, with about 75% borne by public sector facilities. The estimates include the cost of 
reconstruction of lost or damaged buildings, replacement of damaged equipment, replacement 
of staff perished in the disaster, and additional cost of health treatment and public health 
interventions in response to the disaster.  
 
43.  Before initiating the DMRR activities, ETESP will support the development of a strategic 
plan for rehabilitating and reconstructing health services, building on the DMRR blueprint, to 
provide effective approaches for health service delivery to address the health needs and 
placement of population, identify challenges faced by the public sector, and assess strengths 
and complementary support offered by NGOs and the private sector. This assessment will help 
the Government develop a health system that will appropriately address health needs with 
improved efficiency and effectiveness.  
 
44.  The ETESP will go beyond replacing the damaged health facilities, and will restructure 
the health care delivery system with full participation of the affected communities. Health sector 
interventions of the ETESP will (i) design an efficiently functioning and rationalized health 
service delivery network for the province; (ii) strengthen primary health care and its referral links 
to  district  hospitals;  build  sustainable  institutions  of  continuing  education  for  nurses  and 
midwives; and strengthen provincial and district health capacity; (iii) strengthen 15–20 selected 
facilities that provide outreach services for primary health care; and (iv) upgrade and reequip 
about 2–3 district hospitals. Provincial and district health management will receive priority 
attention  in  terms  of  providing  capacity-building  support  for  sector  planning,  coordination, 
management, human resource planning and development, and financial management and 
accounting systems to track the flow of health sector support. This component will also develop 
mechanisms to allow for public-private partnerships in service delivery, training, and monitoring.  
 
45.  Education. The disaster has caused serious damage to the education infrastructure and 
led to the loss of thousands of education professionals. About 600 schools in Aceh and North 
Sumatra are estimated to have been destroyed or damaged extensively. This includes at least 
30 madrasah schools. An estimated 2,500 teachers are estimated to have died, in addition to 
serious losses among education administrators in local governments. About 70,000 children are 
estimated  to  be  among  the  internally  displaced  people.  Many  teachers  and  students  are 
severely traumatized. The impact on poor families has been significant in terms of disruption of 
education services, and imperiling future human resource development and livelihoods of the 
poor in these areas. The need for rehabilitation and reconstruction of schools and madrasah is 
urgent in order to minimize disruption to the education of children and young adults, reduce 
trauma, and bring normalcy to people’s lives. The total cost of rehabilitation and reconstruction 
in the education sector is estimated by the Government at over $700 million, with primary to 
senior secondary schools and madrasahs accounting for $300 million. 
 
46.  ADB’s ongoing projects in basic and higher education provide immediate support for 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  of  schools  and  higher  education  institutions,  cumulatively 
amounting to $16.5 million. Several other donors are involved in the education sector. The 
ETESP will support rehabilitation and reconstruction of educational institutions in phase 2, 
based on a full mapping of the DMRR needs with the support of other development partners.  
 
47.  Skills Development. Close to a million people directly or indirectly affected by the 
disaster will need some form of livelihood support in the next 2–3 years. As a considerable part

15 
of the private sector has been wiped out, people who have lost their livelihoods and out-of-
school youth must be reskilled through vocational training that will help them find employment. 
The ETESP will provide support for training about 6,000 individuals in utility-oriented technical 
areas, such as electrical and electronics, computer, automotive, carpentry, brick-making, and 
sewing.  Appropriate targeting mechanisms will be used to ensure coordination with support 
from the Government and other donors. 
 
3.      Community Infrastructure 
48.  Rural Water Supply and Sanitation. Water and sanitation service coverage in Aceh 
and North Sumatra was below the national average before the disaster. Only about 9% of the 
Aceh population and 24% of North Sumatra inhabitants benefited from piped water supply, 
across rural and urban areas. Similar to many other areas throughout the country, system 
efficiency was low, with nonrevenue water estimated at 30–50% on average. The majority of the 
population, in particular in rural areas, relied on self-provision or community-based systems 
(mostly dug wells and hand pumps), and private small-scale water providers and vendors. Prior 
to the tsunami, the sanitation sector was mainly characterized by on-site sanitation (septic tanks 
and pit latrines), but coverage was extremely low and virtually nonexistent in many rural villages 
of these two provinces. What was existent before has now been completely wiped out in most 
urban and rural areas struck by the tsunami. Data on water supply damage, in particular in rural 
areas, are still sparse and do not include rural sanitation damage and losses. The DLA is likely 
to be substantially revised upward once more detailed assessments are completed. 
 
49.  The improvement of water supply and sanitation facilities for the population in Aceh and 
North Sumatra has reached a new level of urgency. Increases in the incidence of waterborne 
and water-related diseases such as diarrhea, intestinal worms, skin diseases, malaria, and 
dengue are highly probable in the current situation. While the focus during the immediate relief 
phase has been on prevention of communicable disease outbreaks, which have the potential to 
kill many people, concerted interventions will be necessary to (i) ensure that disease outbreaks 
are controlled after phasing out of relief efforts, and (ii) reduce the incidence of waterborne and 
water-related diseases in the provinces in the medium and long term on a sustainable basis. 
 
50.  The ETESP will follow the design of the Aceh-North Sumatra Emergency Assistance 
Grant component under the proposed Community Water Services and Health Project. In phase 
1, the ETESP will provide support to rehabilitate rural water and sanitation facilities in villages 
with repairable damage and extend at least temporary coverage of facilities into communities 
with a large influx of  internally displaced people. Based on progress, feasibility, and spatial 
planning assessments,  the ETESP will develop new facilities in reestablished settlements in 
phase 2.  For new facilities, communities themselves will decide on the type of technology to be 
used, plan and implement the activity with the assistance of community facilitators, take charge 
of  operation  and  maintenance  on  a  permanent  basis,  and  monitor  and  evaluate  the 
sustainability and use of the new services. The provision of appropriate technical solutions at 
affordable  costs  will  be  coupled  with  capacity  strengthening  of  local  governments  and 
communities to ensure the sustainability of the infrastructure provided, through information, 
education, and communication campaigns on waterborne and water-related  diseases; and 
sanitation and hygiene behavioral change programs.  About 150 villages and 80,000 people in 
the affected districts are expected to benefit from the ETESP. 
 
51.  Irrigation. Prior to the disaster, 465 irrigation schemes in Aceh covered over 335,000 
ha. They were classified as government-developed schemes (about 57% of the area) and 
farmers’ schemes (about 43%). Due to poor maintenance, only 70% of the schemes were

16   
functional. The irrigation schemes have suffered both tsunami and  earthquake damage. The 
tsunami damage was caused by the temporary flooding of downstream parts of schemes 
situated relatively close to the coastline. The damage consists mainly of deposits of various 
natures on fields, and partial or complete destruction of the canal infrastructure.  Damage of 
irrigation systems, including technical, semitechnical, and simple systems, are reported in 10 
districts4 in Aceh and 6 districts in North Sumatra,5 although the latter account for only 5% of the 
overall damage. Typical damage includes cracks and occasional displacement/settlement of 
masonry structures, slip failures in canal and river embankments, and collapse of culverts. More 
than 64,000 ha of irrigation schemes in Aceh are reported to have some kind of earthquake 
damage, though information on village irrigation schemes is being still collated. Total damage to 
the Government-developed irrigation schemes is estimated at Rp667 billion ($72 million).  
52.  The ETESP will rehabilitate high-priority, tsunami and earthquake damaged irrigation 
infrastructure with a total service area of about 32,600 ha. In phase 1, rehabilitation support will 
be provided to irrigation infrastructure in the less-damaged areas of the northeast coast of Aceh 
(31,300 ha) and North Sumatra (1,300 ha). Phase 1 will also provide for feasibility studies of 
irrigation schemes covering 7,000 ha in the heavily affected areas on the west coast of Aceh, 
which will be rehabilitated during phase 2.  
 
53.  Provision of Housing within an Integrated Community Development Framework. 
The DLA estimates indicate that about 127,000 houses have been completely destroyed, 
displacing over 400,000 people. Furthermore, about 152,000 housing units were damaged at 
about 50% of their value. The overall damage has been estimated at $1.4 billion, including 
reconstruction and rehabilitation costs, temporary shelter, debris removal, tertiary infrastructure 
repair, and furniture. Much of the damage was concentrated near the coastal zones in  Aceh 
Barat, Aceh  Besar, Aceh Jaya, Banda Aceh and Kota Meulaboh. The losses transcend the 
physical  impact.  While  affected  by  the  civil  conflict,  which  impeded  delivery  of  essential 
services, housing settlements still functioned as homogeneous communities. Many have now 
been torn apart. In many locations land ownership records and planning documents are lost. 
The housing rehabilitation/reconstruction program will be based on the Government’s policy 
decision to grant a 36 square meter core housing unit to all earthquake-tsunami affected 
families, irrespective of their previous housing status. A range of delivery mechanisms will be 
needed,  including  community-based  housing,  support  for  private  housing,  public  housing 
schemes, self-help rebuilding programs, and NGO-provided housing. None of these approaches 
alone would be able to meet all requirements.  
 
54.  The ETESP will cover replacement and repairs of about 24,000 units. Given the urgent 
need of those without any housing, the focus will be on providing new shelters. The housing 
subprojects will be designed in coordination with other development partners likely to provide 
support—World Bank, Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit-Kreditanstalt für 
Wiederaufbau (KfW-GTZ), UN Habitat, and World Vision. The ETESP will facilitate community 
participation and finance community-based housing (both rehabilitation and reconstruction), 
establishment of support centers to provide materials and skilled labor where appropriate, and 
provision of a microcredit facility for house expansions. It will also provide essential additional 
support for neighborhood infrastructure like on-site water and sanitation works; and may also 
cover off-site water and sanitation infrastructure, paths, streets, and basic drainage, which in 
many cases need to be treated as an integral part of such subprojects. Initial priority will be

4.      Physical Infrastructure 
55.  Spatial Planning and Environmental Management. With many areas swept by the 
tsunami, government and other groups see an opportunity to introduce a new land use/zoning 
plan before commencing large-scale DMRR activities. This ETESP component will support the 
rehabilitation and reconstruction process for Aceh and North Sumatra by providing technical 
support, in an adaptive and flexible manner, to the integrated participatory spatial planning 
process, incorporating the dimensions of environmental management and disaster mitigation. 
Community participation in the decision-making process and ownership in the rebuilding of the 
affected areas will be at the core of the activities, and relevant institutional capacities will be 
reestablished. Already successfully tested principles and procedures of integrated coastal zone 
and watershed management in Indonesia provide a framework for decision-making, and will be 
applied and further adapted to the specific context of the tasks ahead. 
56.  In support of the process of planning for a sustainable future for the affected areas, 
environmental criteria for the spatial planning and zoning process will be developed, and 
baseline environment-related information collected. Technical advice will be provided on ADB 
and government policies, laws, and regulations relating to the requirements for environmental 
assessment and to carry out environmental assessments for subprojects, in accordance with 
the environmental assessment and review procedures as they have been set up for the entire 
ETESP.  
57.  Road Sector. Of the six major roads in the affected areas, 22% of the road pavement 
and 10% of the bridges are estimated to be either severely damaged or completely destroyed. 
The road network along the west, east, and north coasts of Aceh province and in Nias Islands of 
North Sumatra province has been damaged with some sections entirely washed away by the 
tsunami waves. On the 294 km Banda Aceh-Meulaboh road, 80 km are missing, 120 km are 
heavily damaged, and almost two thirds of the 171 bridges have been destroyed. The Banda 
Aceh-Krueng Raya road on the north coast and Banda Aceh urban roads have also been 
damaged; about 50% of the 158 km needs to be reconstructed. On Nias Islands, north and 
southwest roads have been damaged.  On about 30 km of the Banda Aceh-Lhoksemauwe-
Bts.Sumut road, located along the east coast, the pavement is cracked partly due to the 
earthquake. Following the destruction of the west coast road, the traffic on the east coast road is 
increasing beyond its capacity. Due to impassable or heavily damaged roads, the traffic is 
diverted through much longer and congested routes. The economic losses due to vehicle 
operating cost increase are estimated at about $100 million equivalent.  Overall damage to 
transport infrastructure is estimated at $178 million.  
58.  The Government has requested ADB to help rehabilitate and reconstruct the east coast 
road (Banda Aceh-Sigli-Lhokseumawe-Bts.Sumut road), Banda Aceh-Krueng Raya road, and 
Banda Aceh urban roads. The total road length to be rehabilitated, including bridges, is 115 km. 
Initial support to rehabilitate 20 km of the affected roads will be provided under an ongoing

18   
project.6 The ETESP will finance the rehabilitation and partial reconstruction of the remaining 95 
km of damaged roads and bridges. Additional assistance may be needed to upgrade and repair 
roads currently under stress due to heavy relief use. This will be monitored during phase 1. 
 
59.  Energy Sector. Damage to public power supply is concentrated in Aceh, particularly in 
Banda  Aceh,  Bireuen,  Meulaboh,  and  Sigli  regions.  The  main  damage  is  to  distribution 
networks. The National Electricity Corporation estimates the damage in these four regions at 
1,485 circuit-km of medium voltage lines, 3,404 circuit-km of low voltage lines, 45 megavolt-
amperes of distribution transformer capacity, and 90,000 household customer connections. The 
150-kilovolt transmission lines and substations are practically unaffected and are functioning 
normally. Damage to generation facilities was also less severe. The main power plants in Banda 
Aceh and Meulaboh only suffered minor damage to transformer and maintenance facilities. A 10 
megawatt barge-mounted power plant has significant hull damage. Taking into account damage 
to  the  distribution  networks,  generation  facilities, and  National Electricity Corporation office 
buildings  and  warehouses,  the  corporation  estimates  the  total  damage  at  $45.6  million 
equivalent. 
 
60.  The ETESP will help restore power supply in the affected regions of Banda Aceh, 
Meulaboh, and Sigli by reconstructing 31 circuit-km of medium voltage and 1,294 circuit-km of 
low voltage distribution lines, and 35 megavolt-amperes of transformer capacity. Most of the 
damaged medium voltage distribution lines will be restored with resources from an ongoing 
project.  The  ETESP  will  focus  on  low  voltage  distribution  lines  as  an  extension  of  the 
reprogramming support.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management  
64.  The Government is expected to issue a Decree establishing the BKP in April 2005 
(para.6), to coordinate the overall implementation of DMRR support in the affected regions. With 
offices in Banda Aceh and Jakarta, BKP will be responsible for all DMRR activities supported by 
any donors, including the MDTF or other bilateral development partners. The structure of BKP,

21 
as per the current plan being formulated by the Government, provides for (i) an implementation  
coordination board to manage day-to-day operations; (ii) a steering board, comprising selected 
cabinet  ministers,  the  governors  of  Aceh  and  North  Sumatra,  and  heads  of  district 
administrations,  to  act  as  a  steering  committee  for  BKP;  and  (iii)  a  supervisory  board, 
comprising various NGOs, universities, and other respected institutions, to provide community 
oversight of DMRR activities. BKP is expected to have six operational departments along 
functional lines. In addition, DMRR activities will be subject to independent external audit.  
Details of the proposed BKP structure are in Appendix 4. 
 
65.  Once established, BKP will be the Executing Agency for the ETESP, with responsibility 
for its overall management and coordination. In the interim, BAPPENAS will function as the 
acting Executing Agency. ETESP subprojects will be implemented by the line ministries and the 
local governments concerned. The relative roles of BKP and the concerned ministries and local 
governments will be guided by the eventual organizational structure of BKP.  For day-to-day 
ETESP  management,  a  dedicated,  centralized  project  management  office  (PMO)  will be 
established within the BKP secretariat to (i) coordinate ETESP implementation; (ii) ensure that 
ADB support is fully aligned with the DMRR strategy; (iii) enhance synergies and ensure close 
coordination  of  ADB  support  with  projects  financed  by  the  MDTF  and  other  development 
partners; and (iv) provide guidance to, and monitor the activities of, the project management 
units (PMUs) to be established in the line ministries. As BKP is likely to face significant 
demands on its resources,  the ETESP will provide support to the PMO to ensure sound 
coordination of subproject implementation. This support will take the form of a dedicated PMO 
manager reporting to the head of BKP, and appropriate technical and administrative staff.  
 
66.  In terms of implementation arrangements at the line ministry and local government 
levels, the ETESP will adopt a simplified structure reflecting the emergency character of the 
assistance. The implementation of subprojects in each sector covered by the ETESP will be 
undertaken by the concerned line ministry, which will act as the Implementing Agency (IA), 
working  in  collaboration  with  the  local  governments  concerned.  Each  IA  will  establish  an 
adequately staffed PMU, which will coordinate with the PMO in BKP. The provincial and district 
governments (through the line bureaus) will work with the PMUs for subproject implementation.  
 
67.  The PMO will be responsible for (i) providing guidelines to the PMUs on the fiduciary 
system, including funds flow and disbursement, procurement, record keeping, and reporting; (ii) 
consolidating and reviewing subproject proposals from the IAs to be submitted for  BKP and 
ADB approval; (iii) providing guidance to the PMUs in the preparation of bidding documents; 
and  reviewing  the  procedures  followed  by  the  PMUs  for  the  procurement  of  civil  works, 
equipment,  goods,  and  related  services  for  all  ETESP  components;  (iv)  making 
recommendations on any special arrangements that may be adopted to provide small grants 
under the livelihood components to the affected communities and NGOs executing selected 
subprojects, as well as on implementation arrangements for community-contracted rehabilitation 
activities; (v) submitting the required withdrawal applications for disbursements, including the 
related  supporting  documentation  and  reconciliation  of  the  imprest  (special)  account;  (vi) 
preparing the consolidated financial reports from the PMUs as required; (vii) preparing and 
submitting progress reports to BKP and ADB; and (viii) coordinating the independent audit of 
subprojects and the PMO itself. The Government has agreed to establish the PMO, and appoint 
the project manager and key PMO staff immediately following the establishment of the BKP. 
ADB has approved advance action to recruit the PMO consultants. 
 
68.  The PMUs will closely liaise with the local government working groups in formulating 
subprojects in line with the DMRR strategy, and will finalize and consolidate sector proposals for

4.  Procurement 
73.  Given the urgent DMRR needs, procurement of goods, services, and works will be 
carried out in a manner consistent with the simplified and expedient procedures permitted under 
the ADB Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy and ADB Guidelines for Procurement. In 
general, ADB procedures for reconstruction assistance after disasters allow maximum flexibility, 
so that project activities can start promptly. National procurement will be the preferred mode for 
all civil works because of the relatively short implementation period, the small size of contract 
packages, and the wide geographic spread of subproject sites. Community participation will be 
encouraged in procurement, and local goods and services will be given priority to encourage 
economic revival in the affected regions. 
 
74.  The  ADB  Disaster  and  Emergency  Assistance  Policy  provides  that  to  expedite 
rehabilitation assistance ADB Guidelines for Procurement may be flexibly interpreted, including 
relaxation  of  international  competitive  bidding  (ICB)  requirements.  In  accordance  with  this 
flexibility, procurement of equipment and materials, when the estimated contract cost exceeds 
$1.0 million should follow ICB procedures, with the bidding and evaluation period each reduced 
to 30 days. International shopping procedures will be followed for contracts between $0.5 million 
and  $1.0  million,  with  bidding  periods  reduced  to  7–15 days. For contracts  costing  the 
equivalent of  $0.5 million or less, local procedures will be followed, with invitation for bids 
published in national newspapers and with bidding periods of 7 days and an evaluation time of 
15 days. Direct purchase procedures will be adopted for contracts up to $0.1 million, with award 
within 7 days.  
 
75.  Civil  works  contracts  with  estimated  values  above  $5.0  million  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ICB procedures, with the bidding and evaluation period each reduced to 30 
days.  For  contracts  with  estimated  values  between  $0.5  million  and  $5.0  million,  local 
competitive bidding procedures acceptable to ADB will be followed, with a bidding period of 15–
21 days and an evaluation period of 15–30 days. Invitations for bids will be published in at least 
two national newspapers of wide circulation to ensure adequate dissemination of information. 
For small contracts up to $0.5 million, limited local competitive bidding will be carried out, with
