V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic Benefits 
94.  The  subprojects  will  be  selected  on  the  basis  of  their  technical  feasibility,  cost-
effectiveness, and contribution to the economic revival process in the affected regions. Given 
the total destruction in many areas, any support is likely to bring significant incremental benefits 
to the affected population. The subprojects under theme 1, anchored on livelihood restoration, 
will bring significant direct benefits through immediate opportunities in agriculture and fisheries, 
sectors that account for over 60% of labor force participation in Aceh. Support for the restoration 
of  housing  assets  will  also  have  beneficial  economic  and  social  outcomes.  By  providing 
essential public services and rebuilding infrastructure, the subprojects under theme 2 will have 
major direct and indirect impacts on economic revival. 
 
B.  Poverty and Other Impacts 
95.  Poverty Impact. By contributing to economic revival and livelihood restoration, the 
ETESP  will  have  significant  beneficial  impacts  on  the  poor.  In  particular,  the  targeting 
mechanisms used will ensure that the poor and vulnerable, including those with inadequate

28   
skills, derive adequate support through the subprojects. A summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy, and a gender action plan are in Appendix 8.11 
 
96.  Environmental Impact. This is a category B project. An overall initial environmental 
examination  (IEE)  was  undertaken  to  assess  generic  impacts  of  each  project  component 
(Appendix 5). The IEE shows that the  ETESP will have a  significant positive impact on the 
environment, including rehabilitating the damaged coastal zones, mangroves, and coral reefs; 
reviving agricultural productivity; and reducing health risks by rehabilitating damaged water 
supply and sanitation facilities. In addition, spatial planning and environmental management, as 
a project component, will promote mainstreaming of environmental considerations into the 
planning process. The IEE also shows that none of the interventions under the ETESP, at this 
stage of design, is anticipated to create any significant adverse impact on the environment, and 
that the potential negative impact in a limited number of cases will be localized, short-term, and 
can be mitigated. Given the emergency nature of the Project, subproject-specific IEEs were not 
prepared,  but  will  be  developed  prior  to  physical  construction  of  the  subprojects.  An 
environmental assessment and review procedure is prepared as part of the IEE (Appendix 5), to 
guide the environmental assessment of subprojects and facilitate institutional arrangements and 
compliance with environmental requirements of Indonesia and ADB. 
 
97.  Resettlement Issues. Since the disaster has led to significant changes in the coastline, 
the DMRR strategy envisages a large-scale spatial planning initiative, part of which will be 
supported by the ETESP. The more than 400,000 internally displaced people pose substantial 
challenges  for  the  provision  of  shelter  and  livelihood  opportunities  to  the  homeless  and 
orphaned, who are now temporarily living in public shelters or with relatives and host families. 
Social strains are already evident. The Government’s current plan includes realignment of the 
coastline, at least in densely populated coastal regions. Civil society consultations are under 
way to  disseminate the Government’s plan. While the Government would prefer decisions 
based  on  consensus  with  community  councils  and  leaders  in  Aceh,  some  involuntary 
resettlement may be necessary. The ETESP adopts a pragmatic phased approach dealing first 
with urgent needs in the areas with low to medium devastation and allowing time for in-depth 
spatial, environmental, and other related assessments to be carried out prior to designing the 
subproject interventions under  phase 2. Most of the rehabilitation and reconstruction works 
under  the  ETESP  are  likely  to  take  place  where  the  destroyed  or  damaged  facilities  or 
infrastructure  were  originally  located.  Even  in  the  case  of  housing,  a  sector  where  land 
ownership issues are likely to arise, efforts will be made to minimize involuntary resettlement. 
Most subprojects are unlikely to trigger resettlement safeguards. However, in the event any 
subproject activity does trigger such safeguards, BKP and the concerned IA will prepare an 
appropriate  resettlement  plan  in  accordance  with  the  agreed  Resettlement  Framework 
(Appendix 6) and submit it to ADB for review and approval before awarding contracts. 
 
C.  Risks 
98.  ETESP implementation involves three major risks. The first relates to the history of 
conflicts in Aceh. The tsunami tragedy has provided a small window of opportunity for both the 
Government and the Free Aceh Movement to discuss the future of Aceh. An interim truce has 
been declared, and peace talks aimed at longer-term resolution have been initiated in Helsinki. 
At the same time, reports of armed conflict and skirmishes continue. Years of hostility may take 
significant efforts and goodwill on both sides to be resolved. ADB’s past projects have faced 
major implementation hurdles in Aceh due to the continuing conflicts. The mitigating factor is the

level of seriousness and commitment that the Government has shown in (i) providing relief and 
humanitarian assistance and its coordination,  (ii) preparing the DMRR strategy, (iii)  being 
sensitive to the need for involvement of Acehnese, and (iv) mobilizing donor commitments. The 
DMRR strategy lays out a multiyear implementation framework, and indications are strong that 
the line ministries in a number of key sectors will use the DMRR support as an opportunity to 
elevate the quality of public services in Aceh over and beyond the predisaster situation. Such 
genuine development initiatives are expected to facilitate resumption of normalcy. 
 
99.  The ETESP design deals with the conflict risk  by recognizing that the  reconstruction 
effort must be fully participatory. Conflict experience elsewhere in Indonesia demonstrates the 
importance of thorough communication and consultations, prior to implementation. To restore 
hope for the future and dignity, people must be given control over their lives. To restore trust of 
local institutions, and nurture satisfaction with the reconstruction program, affected people need 
room  to  participate  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  the  reconstruction  programs. 
Consultations  with  the  community  leaders  (formal  and  informal),  local  academics,  and 
grassroots institutions are first steps in that direction, as they provide an avenue for public 
participation and awareness, and lead to programs that meet people’s needs and aspirations. At 
the same time, care must be taken not to raise expectations about programs and assistance 
that may not materialize. The opportunities for participation must be well researched and 
planned to ensure that the issues raised are representative for all segments in the affected 
communities. 
100.  The second major risk relates to the lack of capacity at the local government levels in 
implementing development programs and projects. The disaster, through loss of lives of scores 
of civil servants, has aggravated the already weak local capacity. The central Government has 
thus far filled the gap by sending teams of experts to deliver essential public services in the 
worst affected areas. The ETESP recognizes these serious problems. The capacity risk will be 
mitigated  by  including  capacity-building  support  for  local  governments  in  all  sector  and 
subproject interventions, and providing adequate consulting support for project management 
and implementation.  
101.  The third major risk relates to coherence of implementation of the Government’s DMRR 
strategy and donor coordination.  ADB assistance will be delivered in an arena with many 
organizations with different targets, programs, and packages of assistance. In addition, the 
multiple needs of reconstruction have different but overlapping targets: regional, sector, and 
individual. Ideally, the DMRR strategy and its future revisions should set out the principles for 
targeting the various schemes proposed. Without coherent principles and criteria, reconstruction 
assistance may induce conflicts. Similarly, the detailed planning of assistance from ADB and 
other donors and their eligibility criteria should be in line with whatever criteria are established 
by the Government, validated by the affected people, and well publicized. The flexible design of 
the ETESP mitigates the risks under this category, by formulating the sector interventions in two 
phases, to allow for time and consultations with the central and local governments and donors. 
The subproject proposals will pass through a comprehensive assessment process, including in-
depth consultations with all the relevant and major institutions concerned. 
102.  In addition, segregation of women and the persistence of gender-based discriminatory 
practices in Aceh may affect the ETESP’s ability to identify the specific needs and vulnerabilities 
of women, especially widows and female heads of households, in order to formulate adequate 
response. To mitigate this risk, ETESP components will support community organizations, 
including  women’s  grassroots  organizations  and  networks,  to  participate  in  local  decision-

30   
making  to  ensure  that  their  perspectives  are  included  in  mainstream  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction efforts.

1.  Agriculture 
a.  Scope 
1.  The agriculture component will cover about 11 affected districts in the Aceh and North 
Sumatra provinces. The first phase districts (Aceh Besar, Aceh Utara, Bireuen, Nias, and Pidie) 
will include those where the majority of the communities in the affected areas are intact and the 
district implementation capacities are not severely affected. The second phase will focus on 
districts where sizable damage has occurred, but need preparatory activities such as restoration 
of accessibility, spatial planning, return of communities from the refugee camps, and restoration 
of some implementation capacity (Aceh  Barat,  Aceh  Barat  Daya,  Aceh  Jaya,  Aceh  Timur, 
Nagan Raya, and Simelue). 
 
2.  Restoration of Support Services. The impact of the tsunami on the agricultural support 
services has been extensive with the loss of trained staff and damage to facilities, equipment, 
and vehicles. To help the recovery of farming, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will support 
agriculture-related human resources and institutional development of district and provincial 
governments in the project area. Drawing on previous ADB and other assisted projects in the 
country, the component will help to (i) introduce extension methodologies, such as participatory 
farmer  field  schools  and  farmer  driven  research,  which  have  proven  to  be  effective  in 
transferring technology to farmers, and (ii) facilitate speedy recovery of farming practice. 
 
3.  The  activities  include  (i)  capacity-building  of  institutions  and  human  resources;  (ii) 
recruitment of agricultural graduates, preferably belonging to the affected areas, on contractual 
basis that may later be absorbed by the district and provincial governments into their regular 
cadres;  (iii)  training  of  250  new  and  350  existing  staff  in  the  participatory  extension 
methodologies, land-use planning, crop production, and remedial measures for salinization and 
other tsunami-related issues; and (iv) rehabilitation of key agricultural facilities, and provision of 
necessary equipment and vehicles. 
 
4.  Community Empowerment. Experience with past and ongoing projects is that the 
formation  and  development  of  self-help  groups  is  highly  effective  in  building  coherent 
communities and enabling community members to rise out of poverty. In select areas, the 
component will support working with community members to revive the communities and build 
their capacities to undertake the recovery process with community participation. The community 
needs and capabilities will be assessed at the initial stages to provide a basis for targeting 
interventions. Revival and empowerment of the communities into self-help groups will also help 
the communities access reconstruction initiatives offered by the Government or other donors.  
 
5.  The component will (i) develop 2,000 self-help groups, (ii) build the capacity of 4,000 
community members in community management skills,; (iii) develop participatory land and asset 
ownership mapping, (iv) undertake a needs and capability assessment, (v) establish community 
microfinance services,  (vi)  provide  training  in  alternate  income  generation  skills,  and  (vii) 
support communities to reestablish land ownership records. The component will specifically 
target households headed by women and orphans to ensure that their interests are protected. 
 
6.  Restoration of Farming. Damage to farmland, supporting infrastructure, and farming 
assets has been extensive. Depending on the extent of damage, restoration of productive 
activities to pre-tsunami levels may take from 6–8 months to 3–4 years. The component will

3.  Microenterprises  
a.  Damage and Impact 
20.  Enterprises in Aceh. Aceh’s economy was dominated mainly by family-owned firms, 
many small and most operating outside the formal economy. Most Acehnese households relied 
on agriculture or fishing as their main source of income. According to the national statistics 
service, only 65 establishments classified as medium or large-sized firms were operating in 
2002. The statistics service’s 2002 survey on small informal business estimated that Aceh had 
187,996 micro and small enterprises, each employing an average of 1.8 people. About 80,000 
of these businesses have been lost, generating job losses of approximately 140,000.  
 
21.  Financial Sector of Aceh. Prior to the disaster, the financial sector comprised mainly 
commercial  banks,  a  provincial  development  bank  (Bank  BPD  Aceh),  and  small  financial 
institutions, most notably 20 rural development banks (BPRs). In the provincial capital of Banda 
Aceh, 10 commercial banks were operating, including Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI), Bank 
Mandiri, and Bank Danamon. Some half dozen insurance companies operating in Aceh, served 
mainly larger businesses. BRI (130 offices) and Bank BPD Aceh (38 offices) had extensive 
operations outside of Banda Aceh and these two banks accounted for 73% of the provincial 
credit outstanding, which amounted to approximately Rp2.6 trillion ($339 million).2 Prior to the 
tsunami,  BPD  Aceh  had  a  loan  portfolio  of  slightly  more  than  Rp1  trillion  ($122  million) 
representing more than 39% of total lending within Aceh. State and privately owned banks 
combined accounted for Rp1.8 billion in loans ($213 million), about 63% of total Aceh lending. 
BRI, with $126 million3 in total loans, had the largest share. BPRs’ combined lending of Rp35 
billion ($4.1 million), amounted to 1.2% of total Aceh credit.  
 
22.  Half of commercial bank loans outstanding as of 26 December 2004 in Aceh equivalent 
to $100 million are subject to write-off, though this figure will ultimately be adjusted downward, 
as credit life insurance was widely in use. Infrastructure losses and damage to records are 
estimated  as  high  as  Rp130  billion.  Six  BPRs  have  been  completely  wiped  out:  offices 
destroyed along with records, high staff casualties, and devastation to their service area. 
Cumulative losses of BPRs and BPD is about 50% of their portfolios and greater than their 
combined capital. Both the local BPRs and the BPD lack back-up lines of credit or liquidity 
facilities that they could draw on to restart lending operations. The BPRs are in a difficult 
situation, as their deposits are being drawn down by customers. Only the BPD has resumed 
lending on any scale. BRI has not yet resumed normal lending and has declared a “repayment 
holiday” to be in effect through the end of March. Most enterprise borrowers are unlikely to 
begin  repaying  until  BRI  has  worked out restructuring/refinance plans with them. BRI has 
announced that it expects to write off Rp400 billion ($47 million), equivalent to virtually the entire 
combined portfolios of three BRI branches (and the units they supervise) destroyed.

institutions4 existed in the tsunami-affected areas, and these appear to have been largely wiped 
out. Prior to the disaster, low cash and capital reserves, geographic concentration, and often, 
inadequate support and supervision worked against the development of grassroots institutions. 
ADB will support establishment of new grassroots microfinance institutions (MFIs), which will 
require  sustained  technical  assistance  for  capacity  building.  Post-tsunami,  however, 
compassion could interfere with the establishment of sustainable grassroots institutions: soft

E.  Fiduciary Governance  
1.  Strengthening Fiduciary Oversight 
a.  Rationale 
91.  Notwithstanding the creation of any new coordinating structures focused on the tsunami 
recovery and rehabilitation, there is an immediate need to ensure that the existing fiduciary 
structures in Aceh and North Sumatra are functioning. This is an essential prerequisite for 
ensuring that the funds utilized for the reconstruction and rehabilitation phase are utilized 
effectively  and  consistently  with  international  fiduciary  standards.  Funds  for  the  tsunami 
reconstruction and rehabilitation effort are likely to be channeled in a variety of ways, including a 
multidonor trust fund. The Government is acutely aware that to ensure that the commitments 
from the donor community are realized into actual contributions, it must present a clear strategy 
on the fiduciary arrangements to the donor community. Given the history of fiduciary weakness 
in Indonesia this issue has to be tackled on a number of fronts. 
 
92.  For this purpose, ADB proposes to leverage its technical advantage in the area of public 
financial management utilizing the analyses and knowledge gained during the processing of 
both the recently approved State Audit Reform (STAR) Sector Development Project17 and the 
technical assistance grant provided to build capacity of the Anticorruption Commission (KPK).18 
Support is focused on the Supreme Audit Agency (BPK), which is expected to take the lead on 
the overall fiduciary arrangements as the external audit of the Government. BPK will coordinate 
with the Government through the proposed Aceh Reconstruction Implementation Coordination 
Board (BP-R2MAS) that will be established and led by BAPPENAS. BAPPENAS is also the 
appointed Government body to monitor support coming from the donor community, including 
support to BPK. 
 
93.  Consistent with the approach taken in the STAR Sector Development Project, BPK 
recognizes that the work of the external audit is very dependent on systems established by the 
executive. The latter involve the funds flow and the internal controls put in place by the Ministry 
of Finance. In addition, a risk-based approach to auditing that recognizes that not everything 
can be audited in detail is very dependent on the effective functioning of internal audit. For 
Aceh, the critical internal audit institutions (BAWADAS) are those operating at the regional level 
of government—the provincial and the district Bawasdas. BPK is keen to engage the Bawasdas 
in Aceh to help ensure that the internal control systems are operating effectively in the districts. 
Some support is also envisaged as necessary for the central internal audit agencies in the line 
ministries, the inspector generals. 
 
94.  BPK  also  recognizes  that  the  donor  community  would  want  to  see  follow-up 
investigations on any anticorruption activities. The two entities that play a key role are the 
Attorney General’s Office and KPK. Unlike the Attorney General’s Office, KPK is a relatively 
new institution, and requires capacity building if it is to be able to carry out investigations on the 
cases referred by BPK. Its processes need to be strengthened and it needs to be provided with 
additional operating budget for specific Aceh cases. This support is expected to allow the 
community at large to recognize the benefits of KPK as a catalyst for change. The Aceh 
activities of KPK will enable it to cement its role in the overall fiduciary framework of Indonesia.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Support Project is categorized as environment 
category B. An overall initial environmental examination (IEE) to assess the generic impacts of 
each project component shows that the ETESP will have a number of positive impacts on the 
environment. These include rehabilitating the damaged coastal zones, mangroves, and coral 
reefs; reviving agricultural production; and reducing health risks by rehabilitating damaged water 
supply and sanitation facilities.  It also shows that none of the envisaged interventions, at this 
stage of project design, is known to be environmentally critical or projected to create significant 
adverse or negative impacts on the environment. The potential negative impacts are localized 
and short-term, and can be mitigated. Therefore, an environmental impact assessment (EIA) is 
not required. In addition, the spatial planning and environmental management component of the 
ETESP will mainstream environmental considerations into the planning process. 
 
2.  Given the ETESP’s emergency assistance nature, subproject-specific IEEs have not yet 
been prepared, but will be developed prior to implementation. To guide the environmental 
assessment  of  subprojects  and  facilitate  institutional  arrangements  and  compliance  with 
environmental  requirements  of  Indonesia  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  an 
environmental  assessment  and  review  procedure  (EARP)  has  been  agreed  with  the 
Government (paras. 14-21). 
 
B.  Description of the Project 
3.  The ETESP has 11 main components: agriculture, fisheries, micro and small enterprise 
support, health, education, rural water supply and sanitation, housing, irrigation, spatial planning 
and  environmental  management,  roads  and  bridges,  and  power.  A  description  of  the 
components is given in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
4.  Physical and Ecological Resources. The tsunami generated a range of environmental 
problems with harm to human health and damage to the environment. It caused widespread 
deposition  of  debris  including  municipal  waste  from  dump  sites,  household  waste,  and 
hazardous substances, and it triggered coastal zone retreat and erosion, coral reef damage, 
loss of marine and terrestrial habitats, soil salinization, destruction of vegetation and landscape,

21.  The ETESP mostly focuses on reconstruction and rehabilitation of existing infrastructure, 
as well as on rebuilding public services and reestablishing institutional capacities to cope with

followed and be fully complied with. The impacts are considered to be controllable through 
implementation of appropriate mitigation measures and environmental monitoring, and through 
the PMO’s readiness to take corrective actions when deemed necessary and recommended by 
the environmental assessment team. The adoption of good construction practices, incorporation 
of mitigation measures during design, inclusion of suitable clauses in construction contract 
documents, and implementation of the agreed mitigation measures during construction will help 
prevent any environmental damage from happening. 
 
22.  In summary, the IEE for the ETESP shows that no significant adverse environmental 
impacts  are  expected  to  result  from  the  proposed  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  work.

subproject is rated as category A, a full subproject EIA for that particular subproject will have to 
be undertaken.

SUMMARY LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The Government Indonesia has requested Asian development Bank (ADB) assistance for the 
Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Support Project (ETESP). The ETESP will assist rehabilitation and 
reconstruction of Aceh through a multisector approach covering housing, education, health, water and 
sanitation, agriculture, natural resources and coastal management, road and power infrastructure, and 
capacity building. Each sector includes various components subdivided in subprojects. Components with 
ground  impacts  include  natural  resources  and  coastal  management,  or  components  requiring 
rehabilitation, reconstruction, or new construction of water and sanitation facilities; housing; health centers; 
school buildings; government offices; irrigation schemes; power distribution networks; and roads and 
bridges. Only subprojects aiming at new construction are expected to involve land acquisition and 
resettlement (LAR). Rehabilitation or reconstruction subprojects will be implemented at their previous sites 
and in general are not expected to involve LAR. 
 
2.  To understand LAR magnitude and potential implementation difficulties, considering the level of 
disruption and destruction caused by the disaster is important. Some of the subprojects areas have 
registered no disruption and some have been partially disrupted and damaged, but continue to host 
functional communities. The scope of subprojects in these areas will be more developmental. However, 
some areas have been completely damaged physically and disrupted socially. In the latter, active 
communities, a functioning government, and a reliable spatial plan will have to be established to allow 
subproject implementation.  
 
3.  As LAR planning and compensation will be much more difficult in areas that have been completely 
destroyed, project activities have been divided in two phases. Phase 1, to begin after approval of the grant 
and its effectiveness and continue until ETESP completion in mid-2008, includes (i) rehabilitation or 
reconstruction activities, (ii) construction activities in areas with no or partial disruption, and (iii) preparatory 
work for phase 2, involving assessment, governance, spatial planning, and community empowerment 
tasks. Phase 2 will begin by October 2005, after the preparatory work under phase 1 has been concluded, 
and continue until ETESP completion. Phase 2 will target construction activities in areas where total 
destruction and disruption have occurred. This strategy will allow work on subprojects without LAR or with 
the simplest LAR cases early in project implementation, thus leaving adequate time to carry out more 
complicated LAR tasks later, after the completion of the necessary due diligence studies. 
 
B.  Resettlement Policy Framework

resettlement  policy  framework  and  implementation  guideline  (LARPFPG)  for  the  ETESP,  as  the 
Government has yet to finalize the establishment of the proposed Implementation Coordination Board for 
Aceh-North Sumatra Rehabilitation and Reconstruction (BKP), which is envisaged to be the Executing 
Agency for the ETESP. The LARPFPG will be approved by the Aceh provincial government and 
implementing agencies. Given the ETESP’s emergency assistance nature, the LARPFPG establishes 
simplified and fast-tracked LAR implementation mechanisms consistent with ADB policies on disaster and 
emergency assistance and involuntary resettlement. 23

C.  ETESP Compensation Eligibility and Entitlements  
6.  LAR will be implemented in accordance with relevant Indonesian laws and ADB policies on 
involuntary resettlement and disaster and emergency assistance. Though Indonesian law (Presidential 
Decree  No.  55/1993)  and  the  ADB  policies  are  generally  consistent,  they  differ  slightly  on  land 
compensation and entitlements of informal settlers. The LARPFPG reconciles these differences by setting 
general principles, compensation eligibility, entitlements, and land donation provisions that are in line with 
ADB policies.  
 
7.  Policy Principles. The LARPFPG outlines the following policy principles: (i) negative impacts will 
be minimized as much as possible; (ii) resettlement and compensation will be carried out to improve or at 
least restore the pre-project living standards of people affected; (iii) those affected will be thoroughly 
informed and consulted on compensation options and resettlement plan design; (iv) land rights of women, 
widows, orphans, and elders without family will be safeguarded; (v) LAR will be executed with thorough 
attention to titling issues; and (vi) as much compensation and resettlement subsidies as possible will be 
provided in full prior to ground leveling and demolition.  
 
8.  Eligibility Provisions. All affected persons  are entitled to compensation or at least rehabilitation 
under the ETESP including (i) people losing Hak Milik (title), Guna Usaha (usufruct), Ulayat (traditional) or 
Waqf (religious) rights; (ii) informal settlers; (iii) tenants and laborers; (iv) owners of buildings, crops, or 
trees attached to the land; and (v) people losing business income. Eligibility for compensation will be 
limited by a cut-off date to be set for each subproject on the day corresponding to the beginning of the 
impact assessment. Affected people who settle in the affected areas after the cut-off date will not be 
eligible for compensation.

D.  LAR Organization and Responsibilities 
11.  Government. The Aceh governor will establish a provincial land acquisition committee for 
overall supervision of LAR policy and funding. The committee will closely coordinate with all other 
agencies involved in rehabilitation and reconstruction of Aceh and North Sumatra, and will include 
an officer in charge of issues related to ADB activities. Each district will establish a resettlement 
committee to be responsible for policy, valuation, and compensation issues.  
  
12.  Field Activities. For day-to-day management of LAR activities in the field, a land acquisition and 
resettlement unit (LARU) will be established in each district. The LARU will report to the district head, who 
will be responsible for distributing and controlling LAR funds. The LARU will be managed by an executive 
officer contracted from the public or private sector who has experience in participatory planning and LAR 
issues. The LARU will consist of a team of variable dimensions to meet needs in the areas of land 
planning  and  impacts,  participatory  planning  facilitation,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  long-term 
rehabilitation planning. Village governments will support LARU activities as required. 
 
13.  Civil Society. Civil society organizations or informal institutions will assist the local governments in 
LARAP and CAP preparation and implementation tasks. Besides representing those affected, they may 
also participate in the administration of LAR or community planning tasks under government supervision 
when feasible and needed.  
 
14.  ADB. In view of the magnitude of the Aceh and North Sumatra rehabilitation and reconstruction 
tasks, ADB will open a regional office in Medan (North Sumatra) and a field facility in Banda Aceh. The 
offices will be staffed with at least one consultant with extensive experience in land administration and 
LAR, and one consultant with extensive experience in community planning. These consultants will 
facilitate LAR and participatory planning by liaising with local governments, supervising the work of ETESP 
consultants, and engaging in project administration tasks related to LARAP and CAP implementation. The 
consultants will also review the documents prepared by ETESP consultants, ensure that these are 
consistent with ADB policies, and contribute as needed to the LARAP and CAP approval process. Finally, 
the consultants will be tasked with capacity building, training, and monitoring activities. They will ensure 
that the PLAC, resettlement committees, and LARUs understand the requirements of the LARPFPG, and 
will organize capacity-building workshops for LARU field teams. For monitoring, the consultants will 
contribute as needed to the selection of external monitoring agencies, review internal and external 
monitoring reports, and suggest solutions to eventual LAR or CAP implementation problems. ADB will 
ensure that capacity in the area of gender and development is sufficient, either among the consultants or 
with nongovernment organizations (NGOs) assisting in the rehabilitation and reconstruction activities.

15.  Vulnerable Groups’ Issues. Households headed by women, widows, disabled persons, orphans, 
or elders without family will receive special assistance for house relocation/reconstruction and will be given 
particular attention. During LARAP or CAP implementation, their land rights will be carefully safeguarded. 
Specific livelihood improvement strategies for their benefit are currently under study for the post-ETESP 
period. These strategies, which may include employment in project activities, training, and microfinance 
loans, will be outlined in the LARAPs.  
16.  Consultation and Participation. Based on a community-driven design, project preparation will 
bring both beneficiary communities and people affected into a continuous participatory process concerning 
LAR and community planning decisions. The LARAPs and CAPs will document this process by listing and

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
 
Disasters drain growth potential, impoverish households, and enable conflicts. Areas affected by a disaster cannot heal 
themselves without comprehensive support to restore access to basic services and enable affected people to regain a 
normal life. The Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Assistance Project (ETESP) covers the sectors essential to 
stemming poverty and restoring growth, and establishes a precedent for a sound rehabilitation and reconstruction 
response for other disaster-affected areas in the future.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting classification: General  
      Intervention 
The tsunami and earthquake resulted in death, injury, loss of assets, and displacement of individuals and communities in 
northern Sumatra. An estimated 200,000 persons are dead or missing, and 400,000 internally displaced. The primary 
impact of the disaster was in Aceh province. The disaster followed nearly 30 years of conflict in Aceh with martial law 
imposed from 2001 to 2003. During this long period, activities by both parties resulted in kidnappings, torture, and 
killings, as well as violence, particularly against women. While Aceh had been one of the better-off provinces, it became 
the third poorest province out of 30 after 2001. The reconstruction and rehabilitation thus comes against a backdrop of 
conflict-traumatized communities and conflict-disrupted economy. The impact of the disaster extends beyond the 
affected 700 villages in Aceh and North Sumatra. The disaster hit a provincial capital and several significant secondary 
towns, destroying business chains and market access for goods produced by the poor. Access to basic services was 
also disrupted by damage to buildings, equipment, vehicles, and roads, and by deaths and injuries of skilled people. 
Teachers and nurses suffered heavily in the disaster as they were the first to respond to the emergency. Destruction of 
houses and buildings stripped individuals and communities of shelter and places to undertake business and participate 
in public and social life. The remaining infrastructure is being strained as are receiving families and communities 
providing temporary support to those displaced. Strains on receiving communities combined with unclear and varying 
external support may lead to conflicts between those indirectly and directly affected. Following the immediate relief 
efforts, a comprehensive plan must to be implemented to restore access to economic and social life. The ETESP is 
essential to restore the region on a path toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
           The principal concern is for women to have equitable access to social life and livelihood restoration. Women have 
particular vulnerabilities and responsibilities due to their reproductive, child rearing, and family-nurturing role. Women are 
also subject to violence in situations where social order has been disrupted, such as during a period of conflict and 
disaster. The 30-year conflict in Aceh has resulted in a high rate of households headed by women and internal 
displacement. As a result, many women are required by necessity to take all responsibility for supporting the household. 
The disaster has resulted in an increase in the proportion of fragmented families, and more women will find themselves 
alone or the sole support for their families. Reconstruction and rehabilitation support must address women’s special 
needs and those related to the household, i.e., reproductive health, shelter, and water supply and sanitation. It must also 
address their need for livelihood restoration. 
 
Normative values in common currency, particularly among the Acehnese, would suggest that women are 
confined to a limited economic sphere. The adoption of Sharia law in 2003 in Aceh province reinforces these 
perceptions. In practical terms, women in the disaster-affected area are important but invisible actors in the local 
economy. Without a gender screen, key opportunities to restore women to social and economic life are likely to be 
passed over. Project interventions should aim at (i) ensuring that women’s roles in the local economy and business 
chain are clearly identified so that opportunities for support and restoration are not overlooked, and (ii) promoting access 
for restoration of women’s assets and economic activities. 
 
  Rehabilitation programs aim to restore affected persons to a higher level of well-being than before the disaster. 
Project implementation must respect local norms while promoting women to have a larger role in social and economic 
life. Some local cultural traditions provide access and social protection. For example, women may have special forest 
areas for collecting firewood or gathering medicinal plants, and the house is traditionally a female asset. Local customs 
that protect women should be understood and reinforced.  
 
  The ETESP components are still in a relatively general form. Hence the gender action plan, at this stage of 
development, is in the form of recommendations rather than specific actions and targets. Specific gender action plans 
will be developed for the subproject components as they are finalized. They will aim to (i) protect women’s rights to 
assets and opportunities, (ii) balance pressures to promote normative values constraining women that are against their 
practical needs and aspirations, and (iii) provide specific support to develop business and entrepreneurial skills to female 
households.
